member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Sqrt(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex)
member.summary: Calculate the square root of a BigComplex number. The second root can be found by the conjugate of the result. You can use this method to get the square root of a negative value (including a BigDecimal value). e.g. BigComplex z = BigComplex.Sqrt(-5);

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Parse(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberStyles,System.IFormatProvider)
member.remarks: Ignoring style parameter for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Parse(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.remarks:
Supported formats: 1. Ordinary real number (integer or floating point), e.g. 12345, 123.45, 123.45e67 etc. The 'e' for exponent can be lower or upper-case, as with normal floating point syntax. 2. Format used by System.Complex.ToString(), with angle brackets and a semicolon. Square brackets, curly braces, parentheses, or no brackets at all are also supported. 3. Standard notation used in maths is supported (e.g. a + bi), with either i or j. The i or j can come before or after the imaginary number, and it can be lower or upper-case.
Also note: - Leading, trailing, or any other whitespace is ignored. - Digit grouping characters (e.g. thousands separators) are allowed, including commas or periods (culture-specific), underscores, and thin spaces. - The real part must come before the imaginary part. In the math notation, either the real or imaginary part can be omitted. - The format (x, y) is NOT supported, because we need to allow the commas as a decimal points (and they could also appear as digit grouping characters). - A null or empty string is taken to be 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Parse(System.String)
member.returns: The BigComplex value represented by the string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.TryParse(System.String,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex@)
member.param: The BigComplex value represented by the string.
member.returns: If the attempt to parse the value succeeded.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.remarks:
I've added support for an alternate format to the one used by Complex.ToString(), namely the conventional "a + bi" notation (and it's variations). Both 'i' and 'j' are supported for the imaginary unit, hopefully to keep both mathematicians and engineers happy.
Upper-case 'I' means the 'i' is placed after the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + 34i Lower-case 'i' means the 'i' is placed before the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + i34 Upper-case 'J' means the 'j' is placed after the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + 34j Lower-case 'j' means the 'j' is placed before the imaginary part, e.g. 12 + j34
If there's no imaginary part, the real part will be formatted like a normal real value. If there's no real part, the imaginary part will be formatted like a normal real value with the i or j placed as a prefix or suffix according to the format specifier. If the value is negative, the sign will come before the number with i or j. e.g. -1.23i, -i1.23, -1.23j, -j1.23
If you want to use this format, the code ('I', 'i', 'J', or 'j') comes *before* the normal format code, or it can be by itself. So, these would all be valid: - I - j - IG - IF0 - iE3 - jN etc.
If you don't include this prefix, then the same format used by Complex will be used, with angle brackets, and a semicolon separating the real and imaginary parts. Each part will be formatted according to the format string (e.g. G, F2, E3, etc.).
The default format code is "G".

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.ToString(System.String)

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.ToString
member.summary: Express the complex number as a string in the usual algebraic format. This differs from Complex.ToString(), which outputs strings like (x, y).

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex.Tan(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigComplex)
member.remarks:
I'm using Formulation 4 from this page:
I *assume* this is the fastest, as it "only" requires 4 power series calculations, but I haven't compared all the methods to verify as yet. There is probably a single power series that converges on the correct result, but I haven't found it as yet.

member.name: T:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.summary: Operators and methods for comparing BigDecimal.

Core partial struct for the BigDecimal type. Contains the core fields and properties, and the constructors. The other partials contain members grouped by purpose.
A BigDecimal is represented internally by a BigInteger value representing the significand, and an int representing the exponent. The value of a BigDecimal can easily be calculated from: value = Significand * 10^Exponent
No trailing zeros are retained in the significand; rather, the exponent is adjusted instead. This minimised the size of the BigInteger being used to store the value. This varies from the scientific meaning of significant digits, which can include significant trailing zeros, but it seems like the right design choice here.
Power, root, exponential, and logarithm methods for BigDecimal.
Struct members relating to BigDecimal numerical methods.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Half)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.remarks: The resulting BigDecimal value is *exactly* the value encoded by the Half, which may not exactly match the value *assigned* to the Half, due to limitations of binary floating point representation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Single)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.remarks: The resulting BigDecimal value is *exactly* the value encoded by the float, which may not exactly match the value *assigned* to the float, due to limitations of binary floating point representation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Implicit(System.Double)~Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal
member.remarks: The resulting BigDecimal value is *exactly* the value encoded by the double, which may not exactly match the value *assigned* to the double, due to limitations of binary floating point representation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FromSciNotation(System.Decimal,System.Int32)
member.summary: Construct a BigDecimal from a decimal significand and an integer exponent.
member.remarks:
This method is useful for converting a value expressed in scientific notation to a BigDecimal. e.g. Avogadro's number, equal to 6.02214 * 10^23, could be converted to a BigDecimal like:
var avnum = BigDecimal.FromSciNotation(6.02214m, 23);

member.summary: Backing field for the Significand property.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Significand
member.summary: The part of a number in scientific notation or in floating-point representation consisting of its significant digits. Also known as the mantissa.

member.name: F:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal._exponent
member.summary: Backing field for the Exponent property.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Sign
member.summary: The sign of the value (-1, 0, or 1).
member.remarks: The same convention is used as for BigInteger: -1 means negative 0 means zero 1 means positive

member.name: F:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal._digitString
member.summary: Backing field for the DigitsString property.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.DigitsString
member.summary: A string containing the digits of the absolute value of the significand. This will not include a leading minus sign if the significand is negative. Also, because the BigDecimal is maintained in canonical form, this string will not have any leading or trailing zeros, unless the BigDecimal is actually equal to 0.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.NumSigFigs
member.summary: Get the number of significant figures.

member.name: P:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.MaxSigFigs
member.summary: This property determines the maximum number of significant figures to keep in a BigDecimal value. After any calculation, the result will be rounded to this many significant figures. This not only helps control memory usage by controlling the size of the significand, but also determines when to halt numerical methods, e.g. for calculating a square root or logarithm. If this property is modified, only new values will be affected by it. If you want to reduce the number of significant figures in an existing value, use RoundSigFigs().

member.name: F:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal._DECIMAL_PRECISION
member.summary: Precision supported by the decimal type.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Pow(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Numerics.BigInteger)
member.summary: Calculate the value of x^y where x is a BigDecimal and y is a BigInteger. Uses exponentiation by squaring for non-trivial parameters.
member.returns: The result of the calculation, rounded off to the current value of MaxSigFigs.
member.exception: If trying to raise 0 to a negative power.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Pow(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.exception: 1. If trying to raise 0 to a negative power. 2. If no real result can be computed.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Pow(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational)
member.returns: The result of x raised to the power of y.
member.exception: 1. If trying to raise 0 to a negative power. 2. If the denominator is outside the valid range for int. 3. If the base is negative, the numerator of the exponent is odd, and the denominator of the exponent is even. In this case, no real result exists (although a complex result will).

member.returns: The nth root of the BigDecimal value.
member.exception: If the degree is zero.
If the radicand is negative and the degree is even.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.IsCanonical(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Checks if the value is in its canonical state, which for BigDecimal means the value should be zero or the significand should be a number not divisible by 10 (i.e. represented by the smallest possible BigInteger). If the significand is 0, then the exponent should also be 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Division(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: Computes division using the Goldschmidt algorithm:
member.exception: If y == 0

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_Modulus(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks:
There are various ways to implement the modulo operator:
This method uses truncated division, to match the behaviour of the operator as used with the standard number types in .NET. It means the result (the remainder) will have the same sign as the dividend (x).
member.exception: if the divisor is 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.op_ExclusiveOr(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: Overloads the ^ operator to perform exponentiation, consistent with common mathematical usage. While C-based languages traditionally use ^ for bitwise XOR, operator overloading in C# allows for a more intuitive use in the context of custom numerical types like BigDecimal, BigRational, and BigComplex. Many C-inspired languages use ** for the exponentiation operator, but this hasn't been done in C# (yet) and isn't possible with operator overloading, as only a small set of standard operator tokens can be overloaded.
member.returns: The first operand raised to the power of the second.
member.exception: If the base is 0 and the exponent is negative.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Round(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Int32,System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Round off a value to a given number of decimal places.
member.remarks: The default rounding mode of MidpointRounding.ToEven is the same as used by similar methods in .NET Core.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.RoundSigFigs(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Round off a BigDecimal value to a certain number of significant figures.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Truncate(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Frac(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Return the fractional part of the value.
member.remarks:
There are multiple ways to define the frac() function for negative numbers:
The definition used in this implementation simply keeps the digits to the right of the decimal point, and keeps the sign. e.g. Frac(12.345) => 0.345 Frac(-12.345) => -0.345 The following expression will be true for both positive and negative numbers: x == Truncate(x) + Frac(x)

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Floor(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Ceiling(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.remarks: This method should not need to be implemented because it's a static virtual method and the default implementation is what we want. However, static virtual methods are not yet supported by Rider so we need this here for now.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal._Shift(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generate a new significand, found by shifting the exponent of the BigDecimal to the provided new exponent. The combination of the result significand and the provided exponent parameter represent a new BigDecimal value equal to the provided value.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ToString(System.String,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary:
Format the BigDecimal as a string. Supported formats are the usual: D, E, F, G, N, P, and R.
Although "D" is normally only used by integral types, in this case both the significand and exponent will be formatted as integers. An secondary code "U" is provided, which follows the precision (if given). - If omitted, the exponent (if present) will be formatted with the usual E[-+]999 format. - If present, the exponent is formatted with "×10" instead of "E" and the exponent digits will be rendered as superscript. Also, a "+" sign is not used for positive exponents, and the exponent digits are not zero-padded. Example: "E7U" will format as per usual (E with 7 decimal digits), except using Unicode characters for the exponent part. Codes "R" and "D" will produce the same output. However, the Unicode flag is undefined with "R", because Parse() doesn't support superscript exponents.
member.exception: If the format specifier is invalid.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Format the BigDecimal as a string.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.PreformatFixed
member.summary: From a BigDecimal, extract two strings of digits that would appear if the number was written in fixed-point format (i.e. without an exponent). Sign is ignored.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatFixed(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the BigDecimal as a fixed-point number with a given precision.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatFixedSigFigs(System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format as fixed point, except in this case the precision is the number of significant figures, not the number of decimal places. Note, this is not technically formatting as significant figures, since trailing 0s following the decimal point are not retained, as per the usual format for "G".

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatScientific(System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the value using scientific notation.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatExponent(System.String,System.Numerics.BigInteger,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.IFormatProvider)
member.summary: Format the exponent part of scientific notation.
member.param: The original format code (e.g. E, e, G, or g). We need to know this to determine whether to use an upper- or lower-case 'E'.
Whether to use Unicode or standard format.
The minimum number of digits in the exponent (typically 3 for E and 2 for G). Relevant for standard (non-Unicode) format only.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.FormatRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern:
^(?<format>[DEFGNPR])(?<precision>\\d*)(?<unicode>U?)$
Options:
RegexOptions.IgnoreCase
Explanation:
○ Match if at the beginning of the string.
○ "format" capture group.
○ Match a character in the set [D-GNPRd-gnpr].
○ "precision" capture group.
○ Match a Unicode digit atomically any number of times.
○ "unicode" capture group.
○ Match a character in the set [Uu] atomically, optionally.
○ Match if at the end of the string or if before an ending newline.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.RemoveIgnoredCharacters(System.String,System.Globalization.NumberFormatInfo)
member.summary: Removed ignored characters from a string we want to parse, i.e. whitespace and digit grouping characters, which includes the usual comma or period (depending on the culture specified by the NumberFormatInfo parameter), as well as underscores and thin spaces.
member.returns: The string with the ignored characters removed.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Atan2(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: This two-argument variation of the Atan() method comes originally from FORTRAN. If x is non-negative, it will find the same result as Atan(y / x). If x is negative, the result will be offset by π. The purpose of the method is to produce a correct value for the polar angle when converting from cartesian coordinates to polar coordinates. It also avoids division by 0 exceptions.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal.Atan2Pi(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal,Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigDecimal)
member.summary: Computes the arc-tangent for the quotient of two values and divides the result by pi.
member.exception: If x and y both equal 0.

member.name: M:Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational.CompareTo(Galaxon.BigNumbers.BigRational)
member.remarks: Although the specification says any negative value indicates the "this" operand comes before the "br" operand (similar for positive values), in this method the result is constrained to only 3 possible values: -1 means "this" comes before (and is less than) "br" 0 means they are equal 1 means "this" comes after (and is greater than) "br"

member.summary: The denominator of the rational number.
member.remarks: This value should always be positive. It should never 0 because this would not be a rational number. It should also never be negative. The sign of the rational is determined by the numerator.
